conclusion: To determine whether the accelerations of both objects (A and B) are first increasing and then decreasing during the time interval from 0 to t1, we need to analyze the slope of the velocity-time (v-t) graphs.
The graph shows velocity v on the y-axis and time t on the x-axis. The curves represent the velocities of objects A and B over time.
Acceleration is the rate of change of velocity with respect to time. On a v-t graph, acceleration is represented by the slope of the velocity curve.

premise: Acceleration is represented by the slope of the velocity curve.
conclusion: The slope of the tangent line at any point on the curve indicates the acceleration at that point.

premise: The slope of the tangent line at any point on the curve indicates the acceleration at that point.
conclusion: If the slope is increasing, acceleration is increasing. If the slope is decreasing, acceleration is decreasing.
For both objects A and B, notice the direction of the slope changes as time progresses. Initially, both curves have a positive slope, indicating positive acceleration.
As time progresses towards t1, the slope of both curves starts to decrease, indicating the acceleration is decreasing.
The illustration shows tangent lines at different points on the curves. The tangent lines illustrate that the slope (acceleration) increases initially and then decreases.

premise: The slopes of their respective curves first increase and then decrease.
conclusion: For both objects A and B, the acceleration first increases and then decreases over the time interval from 0 to t1.
